• De belangrijkste accountingregels en -conventies toe te passen op bedrijfsactiviteiten
• Jaarrekeningen te analyseren en de resultaten te interpreteren
• De limieten van jaarrekeningen kritisch te evalueren in het licht van de SDGs
• In teamverband hun visie te articuleren en bij te dragen aan het teamresultaat

column1: Financial statements are the principal means of communicating about the performance of a business to outsiders. The objective of this course is not to train you to become accountants but to help you become critical users of financial statements. The achievement of this goal requires an understanding of the concepts and techniques that underlie financial statements and an appreciation for the amount of judgment required in applying accounting concepts. Topics include: the fundamental concepts and techniques underlying financial statements, the accounting treatment of various financial statement items (e.g., inventory, receivables, long-term operating assets, liabilities, and shareholders‚Äô equity) and the analysis and forecast of financial statements. The course ends with a critical evaluation of the limitations of financial statements and reflects on questions such as: Are the information needs of all stakeholders met? Do the financial statements help users to understand how companies are contributing to the United Nations‚Äô Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)?

column1: After completion of the course, the student should be able to:

column2: • Use a critical attitude to structure business challenges, by employing accounting tools and techniques
• Explain the accounting concept of income and accrual accounting
• Explain the purpose of the different components of financial statements
• Explain how the main items in financial statements are measured
• Apply the most important accounting rules and conventions to business events
• Analyze financial statements and interpret the results of the analysis
• Critically evaluate the limits of financial statements in light of the SDGs
• Articulate views in a team and contribute to team performance

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In the ‚Äòdatafication‚Äô age when the myriad dimensions of reality can be quantified and analysed, one important question for companies is who within the organization will capitalize on the technological advances and prepare the business for a dynamic future? Accountants and financial managers who embrace technological innovations can be indispensable organizational resources.

More concretely, this course examines how companies generate, manage, and analyse information using Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) and Business Intelligence (BI) systems and techniques like Continuous Auditing (CA) and process mining. The focus is on the description of activities and data trail involved in the main business processes (e.g., sales, purchasing, production, and payroll). Documentation tools, such as data flow diagrams (DFD), flowcharts, and business process diagrams (BPD), are introduced in the course to illustrate the processes and to assess their efficiency and effectiveness. Hands-on experience with an actual Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) system reinforces the conceptual learning, exposes students to real-world business processes, and enhances the acquisition of IT skills.

Accountants are experiencing a rapid evolution of their roles due to the adoption of new technologies for business reporting, such as XBRL, and to the exponential growth of available data. Several companies submit their financial statements in XBRL format. Accountants play a major role in the preparation of the reports and benefit from the automatic processing of information. The course covers the main features of XBRL, the basics of the language, and the most important implications for managerial reporting, auditing, and decision making.

Big Data summarizes the increase in volume, velocity and variety of data and requires new technologies to measure, analyse, and interpret information. Techniques such as data mining and predictive analytics are discussed in relation to their role of identifying growth opportunities, improving forecasting and planning and hence decision making within the organization.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of this course students are able to:

column2: • Identify the organizational functions and the documents involved in the main transaction cycles (e.g., revenue cycle, expenditure cycle, and conversion cycle);
• Create and interpret data flow diagrams and flowcharts to make inferences about information system effectiveness and process behaviour;
• Recognize the key phases of the system development life cycle, describe planning techniques, and discuss the various types of feasibility analysis;
• Understand how Continuous Auditing through process mining can help organizations ensure effectiveness and efficiency of operations and reliability of reporting;

• Navigate in an Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) system, perform the main steps of a transaction cycle, and extract relevant information for control and managerial decision making. Understand how Business Intelligence tools can facilitate decision making;
• Understand how eXtensible Business Reporting Language (XBRL) is used for financial and managerial reporting in an international business context;
• Understand how Big Data enhances decision making support and apply data analysis tools and techniques (e.g., data mining, predictive analytics) to analyse Big Data;
• Discuss and conclude in teams multiple viewpoints on a particular accounting analytics case, and present and defend the joint findings in a class setting.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>Accounting Process Management deals with the acquisition, storage, and processing of data about an organization's various business activities (e.g., sales, purchasing, production, and payroll). A related term commonly used for such activities is the Accounting Information System (AIS) and throughout this course, the terms APM and AIS will be used synonymously. An AIS produces information that managers within the organization use for controlling various business activities and to make strategic decisions. The information is also used by other employees to complete operational tasks (e.g., sales orders, picking tickets). Aside from internal use, the information also flows out of the organization (e.g., financial statements) to external users such as investors, suppliers and regulators, who have an interest in the firm. Information is only useful to internal and external users if it is reliable, relevant, understandable and accessible. The major purpose of Accounting Process Management is to design, implement and maintain controls which ensure:

column2: • Systems reliability;
• Valid, accurate and complete processing of data;
• Effective and efficient business processes;
• Safeguarding of assets and data, and compliance with laws and regulations.

column1: During this course we will study several elements of Accounting Process Management:

column2: • The data processing cycle (which transforms transaction data into information) and the corresponding manual and computer-based accounting concepts;
• The causes of management and employee fraud and how internal controls can help minimize such threats;
• Overall frameworks and underlying concepts for instance the ""COSO"" framework and the Business Balanced Scorecard;
• Some of the organization's fundamental transaction cycles.
• Previously acquired knowledge on data processing, risk assessment, and control procedures will be applied to these cycles;
• A typology of organizations that helps to identify threats and controls for a variety of organizational types;
• The fundamentals of information systems reliability and how IT-based controls can help maintain reliability;
• Systems development activities and the controls necessary to prevent systems development failure.
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: accounting Process Management controls.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the data processing cycle and the organization's fundamental transaction cycles.

• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the causes of management and employee fraud, the fundamentals of information systems reliability, systems development activities and the controls necessary to prevent systems development failure.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: overall frameworks and underlying concepts.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: typology of organizations.
• Students are able to: design, implement and maintain Accounting Process Management controls.
• Students are able to: interpret, discuss, clarify, illustrate, classify and explain the cycles, reliability, frameworks and typology of organizations and its Information Systems.

column1: This course is about doing the right thing while practicing professional accounting. One part of doing the right thing is knowing what you are expected to do in various situations and recognising what will be the effect of our choice taken while practicing professional accounting.

The hardest part of doing the right thing is, therefore, recognizing and avoiding ethical hazards with conflicting expectations. Accountants have special obligations and responsibilities beyond those of other business practitioners so this course aims to develop the ethical analysis of different scenario beyond philosophy ethics courses and beyond business ethics courses.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course consists of eight sessions, that combine the following three elements: Econometric theory, paper discussions, and STATA exercises (most importantly in-class paper replications). In the ninth session, previously assigned groups present the results of a paper replication. The tenth session is a refresher class about the previously discussed topics tailored to the needs of the students.
Presentations, interactive discussions and in-class STATA exercises are the main teaching methods used in this course.

I expect students to be prepared to perform statistical analysis during the lectures, in other words, to get the most out of the course, students should bring a laptop with a working version of STATA.
Attendance is mandatory for 9 out of 10 lectures.

column1: The 5 day Action Planning workshop is a one week, practical exercise that simulates the reality of a using a multi-stakeholder, integrated approach to developing a strategy and action plan for a neighbourhood. The workshop is structured in steps and students use specific planning tools, applying these to a case study. The planning cycle, starting with problem identification and concluding with the development of a strategy and implementation plan, forms the basis for Action Planning.

Students work with a case study that highlights a series of complex issues in different urban sectors. One of the main challenges students face is that they must develop a strategy that is integrated and takes into account the issues faced in different sectors, without having one strategy in one sector negatively impact another. Each case is different but sectors may include: space and place, land and housing, economy and wellbeing, environment and climate change, large scale /social infrastructure and basic services. The final strategy must also balance the different needs and interests of various actors and stakeholders.

column1: <body>After the module, students should be able to:

column2: • Describe the Action Planning process and provide practical examples of each of its steps
• Work with and apply key tools for decision making, as part of the Action Planning process
• Develop an integrated Action Plan, working in a multidisciplinary group
• Simulate the organization and implementation of  a participatory planning process
• Present and communicate the Action Plan to an audience of professionals and the community.

column1: Actoren in de rechtshandhaving gaat over het functioneren in de praktijk van de actoren en instanties die zich bezighouden met de bestrijding van criminaliteit en onveiligheid.

In de eerste plaats gaat het daarbij om de klassiek strafrechtelijke instanties, zoals de Nationale politie, het Openbaar Ministerie, de rechtspraak en instanties die verantwoordelijk zijn voor de ten uitvoerlegging van sancties, zoals de Reclassering en het gevangeniswezen. Maar de bestrijding van criminaliteit en onveiligheid is al lang niet meer exclusief het domein van politie en justitie. In toenemende mate zijn ook andere, niet-strafrechtelijke, actoren en instanties betrokken bij de bestrijding van criminaliteit en onveiligheid. Te denken valt daarbij aan de handhaving van bijzondere wetten door toezichthoudende instanties, zoals de Autoriteit Financi√´le Markten, de Belastingdienst en de Autoriteit Consument en Markt. Maar ook de bestuurlijke overheid, in het bijzonder gemeenten, heeft de laatste jaren een steeds grotere rol gekregen bij de bestrijding van overlast in het publieke domein. Tot slot zijn bij de bestrijding van criminaliteit en onveiligheid ook private actoren en instanties betrokken, zoals burgers, verzekeringsmaatschappijen en beveiligingsbedrijven en vinden er allerlei vormen van publiek-private samenwerking plaats.</body>

column1: In deze module worden de seminale werken van de Schotse filosoof Adam Smith (1723-1790) over de verbanden tussen moraliteit en economie geduid in de context van de religieuze en intellectuele cultuur van zijn tijd. De ontwikkelingen in de zestiende eeuw, Johannes Calvijns denken over economie en diens impact als uitgangspunt nemend, wordt in het eerste deel van de module licht geworpen op de protestantse c.q. Schots-presbyteriaanse invloed op zowel het ontstaan van de bourgeois cultuur als op het denken van Smith. In het tweede deel van de module worden de concrete filosofische bronnen onderzocht, die Smith ter beschikking stonden en die ten grondslag lagen aan Smiths visie op de markteconomie.

column2: <title></title>

column1: Het bieden van een overzicht van de ontwikkelingen in het denken over de economie in de Reformatie en duiding van de belangrijkste themata in het werk van Adam Smith over de markt, de economie en moraliteit in het licht van het presbyterianisme en de leer over de voorzienigheid die daarin gestalte kreeg.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85648,2019,Addiction,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['prof.dr. IHA Franken'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Addiction is an important problem at both societal as well as on the personal level. Only recently, addiction has been approach scientifically. Last 15 years there is a major international effort to acquire more knowledge about addiction. Through these international efforts we know a lot more about the mechanisms of addictive behaviors. Where addiction used to be seen as personal weakness, new insights within psychology, psychiatry and neuroscience have now clearly put addiction on the map as a psychological disorder, and not a flaw in the character. About time, because addiction is a disorder that is in the top 3 of most common psychological disorders. Recent developments do not only show there is progress in the theoretical aspect, but also in science-driven and effective treatments.

In this course the gap is bridged between the student and recent scientific insights. Different aspects of addiction will be discussed. Firstly, the background of the problem is described, such as the history, definitions and epidemiology of addiction.
In the second part, several theoretical perspectives are presented, namely the psychological and the neuropsychological models.
In the third part, the focus is on practice of treating addiction and addiction-related problems. Several different treatments are described and diagnostics will be discussed.

In the fourth part, behavioral addictions (such as gambling, game addiction and smoking) will be taught. During this course there is the opportunity to hear guest lecturers from the field (e.g., Bouman GGZ, Rottterdam), including an interview with a patient with an addiction.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

During this course students acquire knowledge about (neuro)psychological theories that explain the development and maintenance of addiction. In addition, knowledge will be gathered on the organisation of addiction care/mental health care in terms of addiction and the content and efficacy of several forms of treatment. Because addiction is a complex disorder and hardly ever is a single disorder, special attention will be paid to comorbidity.

column1: Economic agents often do not behave as the rational Homo Economicus. In behavioral economics the standard economic models and theories are adapted to incorporate the economically most relevant findings from psychology. Thereby, behavioral economic research strives to develop models with a higher predictive power than standard economic models. The challenge for behavioral economics is to maintain the balance between predictive power and complexity of the models.

This course will give an up-to-date overview of the most relevant behavioral economic models. Students will learn the differences between the various models. This will enable them to recognize which type of model is most appropriate in specific contexts.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Students learn the most common alternatives to standard economic decision models. Topics covered are decision making under uncertainty, decision making over time, and social preferences.
• Students learn to derive behavioural predictions from the decision models discussed.
• Students learn to recognize whether or not observed behaviour satisfies a particular model.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85987,2019,Advanced Behavioural Finance,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['R Barahona'],,Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Over the past several decades, the dominant paradigm in financial research has been the rational expectations hypothesis based on the notion that investors and managers are generally rational. The rational expectations hypothesis leads to the efficient market hypothesis, which stipulates that asset prices incorporate all available information.

However, anecdotal evidence as well as theoretical and empirical research show that the rational expectations paradigm is insufficient to describe various characteristics of financial markets. Behavioral finance is another approach to studying financial markets. It argues that certain financial outcomes can be better explained and understood using models in which some agents are not fully rational.

This course examines how the insights of behavioral finance complement the traditional paradigm and sheds light on asset price determination, corporate finance decisions, and various Wall Street institutional practices. The course focuses on the application of behavioral finance to two main topics: corporate finance and investments.

Corporate finance aims to understand the financial decisions of companies and extensively deals with agency problems arising from the separation of ownership and control between shareholders and managers. In the course, we will study both the case in which rational managers interact with less than fully rational investors (e.g., in the context of market timing theories) as well as situations where managerial behavior is less than fully rational (e.g., due to managerial overconfidence), and explore the implications for corporate financial decisions such as investments, M&A activity or capital structure.

Another fruitful application of the concepts of behavioral finance is to financial bubbles, defined as prolonged periods of rising prices to levels inconsistent with fundamental economic assessments. The rising prices are subsequently followed by sharp declines, sometimes even price crashes. During the course, we will analyze the conditions that create a bubble in experimental settings as well as review recent financial bubbles such as the Dot-com bubble or the U.S. housing bubble.

In the investments section of the course, we will study behavioral biases in individual investors' portfolio choices leading to insufficient or naive diversification, excessive trading, etc. Next to direct (stock) investments we will also look at issues related to the investment in mutual funds (e.g., return-chasing behavior, mutual fund benchmark distortions), accounting for the fact that, nowadays, individuals invest the vast majority of their savings through financial institutions. The course may touch upon various other topics including the implications of behavioral biases amoung institutional asset managers, and the question of whether individual financial decisions can be improved through education.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Students have knowledge of and insight into the recent and rapidly expanding literature on behavioural finance.
• Students have understanding of how behavioural finance differs from traditional financial theory.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into the effects of psychological biases on financial decision making.
• Students have knowledge of alternative methods to study financial decision making.
• Students are able to distinguish behavioural approaches to finance from traditional ones.
• Students are able to recognize behavioural biases in decision making, for both their own decisions and others.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course covers the more challenging and complex issues that analysts, investors, and financial advisors encounter when they evaluate company performance and value firms. We have selected three analytical challenges that will be discussed in more detail:

column2: • Understanding corporate risk management: We will explain the motives for risk management, how risk management is captured in the financial statement and whether risk management makes sense from an investor‚Äôs perspective. We will use case studies including Alcatel-Lucent, EADS and Lufthansa.

• Challenges in valuation: We will discuss various complexities in enterprise valuation, such as how to analyse, value, and account for non-equity claims and deal with valuation of conglomerates, private firms and spin-offs.

• Financial analysis and valuation of banks: Our aim is to explain the accounting and valuation for banks. We will discuss the valuation and accounting for banks by using the examples of global banks JP Morgan, HSBC and Goldman Sachs.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The academic field of corporate finance examines the financial decisions made by business enterprises. An important part of corporate finance deals with the capital structure of the firm. Research on capital structure can provide tools to minimize the costs of obtaining financing for firms‚Äô investments. The goal is to find the optimal mix of debt, equity and hybrid securities. Theories argue that firms choose between debt, equity, or hybrid securities to minimize costs that arise due to asymmetric information, agency problems, financial distress, and tax considerations.

Another important financial decision for firms is whether to engage in mergers. Researchers have attempted to answer whether mergers add value, and in which circumstances. There could be very good reasons for firms to do a takeover. On the other hand, agency problems might be able to explain why firms sometimes engage in mergers that destroy value.

Agency problems occur because, even though shareholders are the owners of many corporations, it are the managers that make the day-to-day decisions. Managers could have different incentives than shareholders. For example, managers might have a tendency to overinvest in mergers as this could increase their status and salary.

The difference in incentives between shareholders and managers highlights the importance of corporate governance. Corporate governance is the field in finance that deals with ways in which firms are governed and thus the extent to which investors can assure themselves that managers act in investors‚Äô best interest. The interest in corporate governance has increased substantially after a number of accounting scandals in the 21st century, in which the financial results of firms were misrepresented. The goal of good corporate governance is to avoid (accounting) fraud and to increase firm value by assuring that managers only pursue value-creating investment opportunities. Setting an appropriate executive compensation package is an important part of corporate governance.

The first part of the course provides students with advanced knowledge in capital structure theories that build on taxes, financial distress, and agency costs (static tradeoff theory), information asymmetry (the pecking order theory), and market timing. The second part of the course describes the developments in mergers and in corporate governance. Several practice problems and business cases will be discussed. </body>

column1: <body>This course follows a problem-solving approach that synthesizes ideas from game theory, real options, and strategy for corporate decision-making. Corporate finance and corporate strategy have long been seen as different sides of the same coin. Though both focus on the same broad problem, investment decision-making, the gap between the two sides -- and between theory and practice -- remains large. This course synthesizes cutting-edge developments in corporate finance and related fields -- in particular, real options and game theory -- to help bridge this gap. The course covers a wide range of valuation examples, such as firm valuation, private equity acquisition strategies, R&D investment in high-tech sectors, joint research ventures, product introductions, investments in infrastructure, and oil exploration investment. The course will be given in close cooperation with people and organizations that are active in corporate finance, such as private equity investors, investment banks, and consultants. The course Corporate Finance and Strategy is structured in two modules. The first module introduces you to both traditional and new valuation principles for strategic investment. We review the basic concepts and foundations of the building blocks:

column2: • Traditional DCF-valuation (WACC- and APV-method)
• Strategic management
• The valuation of real options
• Games and bidding strategy

column1: This part provides an overview and develops step-by-step the various principles useful for valuation and analysis. Questions addressed include amongst others:

column2: • How can one determine the value of a project or a firm?
• What is the value of a license that gives the firm an option to invest in commercial production of a new product?
• How is the optimal investment policy influenced by competition? How does competition affect the premium being paid in M&A?

column1: In the second module we discuss various applications and examples of private equity investment, acquisitions, and initial public offerings. Lectures by guest speakers will be an integral part of the course and provide an opportunity to become better acquainted with corporate finance in practice. This course provides the fundamentals for the seminar Advanced Corporate Finance and Private Equity.</body>

column2: <title></title>

• Students are able to apply valuation models in a variety of contexts, such as firm valuation, private equity acquisition strategies, R&D investment in high-tech sectors, investments in infrastructure, and oil exploration investment.
• Students are able to form an opinion based on different perspectives acquisitions and private equity investment.

column1: In the new structure the lectures will be used to illustrate applications, inspire, and motivate students, while the content is supported by digitization.
Tutorials are used to guide students through the assignments and to discuss a case study.
First, we organized (sub) groups of smaller scale to support intensive forms of learning using case studies and assignments.
Second, we digitized this course with 3 types of webcasts for content and assignments.

1. For each lecture, a  2D animation video provides an overview.  In these animations we focus on the core of the course or of the lecture. Through the use of animations we simplify complex content and make it accessible to all students.

2. Advanced content videos provide in-depth content. These in-depth videos (varying between 5 and 10 minutes) can be used by students to prepare themselves for lectures and as a study preparation for the exam.

3. Assignment videos are useful as a preparation for question problems for the tutorials and as an exercise for the exam. Students can use these assignments to test their own knowledge and problem-solving skills. These assignment videos focus on difficult calculations.</body>

column1: At the centre of this course will be the recent advances in the development economics. The focus will be on the recent empirical literature. Students will need to read every week one research paper and have to hand in various assignments.
Topics discussed in class will include the role of human capital (health and education), access to financial services and the role of institutions in improving the lives of the poor.

Human capital is considered to be one of the most important determinants of economic growth and poverty reduction. Within the field of development economics several field experiments have been implemented to study how to improve access and demand of health care and attendance and performance of students in school. Also, the provision of financial services (credit, savings accounts, insurance) to poor people is a big challenge for the developing world. In the recent years, many countries experienced the ""microfinance revolution"", but access to formal savings accounts or insurance remains scarce. National and local institutions play an important role in shaping the economy and small changes can be crucial for improving the lives of many.
The final content and structure of the course will be discussed in the first session.

• To study and present in groups at least one scientific article on a subject linked to the course.

column1: The course begins with the illustration of the definition of the cultural industries, then it focuses on a general analysis of the economics of the firm and of markets (industrial organization) and of the institutional and policy framework in which the cultural industries operate. The course builds up to an economic analysis of technological change in the cultural industries and the implications for all types of stakeholders.
To ensure that all participants have a fair chance of performing well, all students must have passed an elementary course in the principles of microeconomics.

column1: <body>The aim of this course is to develop students' understanding of the economics of the cultural industries. The course encourages students to apply economic analysis to an industry of their choice. Like any course in applied economics, this course stimulates students to use theory for developing logically consistent explanations of developments in the cultural industries and for making well-founded predictions. Successful students will also learn to appreciate the limitations of theory, explanation and predictions.</body>

<body>This course builds on the knowledge acquired during Health Technology Assessment. The focus of the course is more economical than HTA. Several methodological problems in economic evaluation will be treated. The problems treated are typically issues that are at the center of the scientific debate. Students will be encouraged to think actively about these issues and formulate their own opinions in a balanced way.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Students should obtain a sound understanding of the methodological difficulties surrounding economic evaluation of health care and their possible solutions. An important aim of the course is to encourage critical reflection on the tools used in economic evaluation of health care.
After completion of this course, the student:

column2: • Is able to formulate their own opinion about methodological problems in economic evaluation in a balanced way.
• Has a sound understanding of the methodological difficulties surrounding economic evaluation.
• Is able to reflect critically on the tools used in economic evaluation of health care.
• Understands the pros and cons of cost-utility analyses and cost-benefit analyses.
• Knows about social welfare theory and the assumptions behind it.
• Understands discounting theory and the assumptions behind it.
• Can explain the relationship between discounting and utility of life duration.
• Can develop their own plan for health utility measurement within economic evaluation.

column1: The course consists of lectures on cultural economics, the application of the economic framework to the performing arts, visual arts and heritage. Topics discussed include: demand and supply of cultural goods; the role of prices; the economic rationale for public intervention in the arts; the economics of performing arts, museums and the art market; artists' labour market and public finance of the arts.

Note: This course is only open to BA students in Cultural Studies and exchange students with some basic knowledge of economics (e.g. high school level of economics). The lectures of this course are mandatory.

column1: <body>The aim of the course is to develop students' understanding of economics as it applies to the world of the arts and culture. Cultural economics studies economic decision-making by artists, organizations, policy-makers and consumers in the cultural sector. The course surveys economic theories about the arts, teaching students how to evaluate the economic aspects of cultural policy and the market for cultural goods and services.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/88122,2019,Advanced Economics of Regulation,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,[],,Inhoud

This course is designed to provide students with advanced skills on the enforcement of law in the field of regulation of markets. In particular, students learn how to use economic arguments and economic evidence in real-life cases in courts and/or regulatory agencies. The course is organized in a moot court format. Students must take the role of plaintiffs, defendants, regulators or regulatees. They are supposed to base their arguments and decisions, both orally and in writing, on economic analysis of law. The topics, which are reviewed yearly, include inter alia competition law, product liability, mergers and acquisitions, financial and consumer law.
This course is open for EMLE students only.</body>

column1: <body>This course provides a thorough understanding of key results from the academic literature on optimal taxation. The course is largely normative in its scope, and addresses the following questions and more: What are the distortive costs of taxation? Should commodity taxes be differentiated? How should marginal income taxes vary with income? What is the optimal tax rate for top incomes? Should capital income be taxed? And if so, why? What is the role of taxation in a risky economic environment? What is the role of corporate income taxation? If the government can redistribute income with progressive taxes, is there still a role for other instruments such as the minimum wage? The course consists of two weekly Lectures that deal with the above questions in detail. Every Lecture has a dual goal: to provide students with a thorough understanding of theoretical underpinnings, and to discuss the practical implications, of the academic field of optimal taxation. At the end of the period, students‚Äô understanding of the material will be tested by means of a final closed-book exam.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• To gain knowledge on the principals of optimal taxation.
• To understand how taxes affect market outcomes, efficiency, the distribution of resources, and social welfare.
• To understand how taxes can optimally strike a balance between equity and efficiency.
• To understand how taxes can optimally strike a balance between equity and efficiency.
• To apply the insights from optimal taxation to actual policy debates.
• To provide a reasoned, critical assessment of much of the tax system in the Netherlands (or any other country).
• To be able to derive and interpret simple rules for optimal policy.

column1: Cost-effectiveness studies aim to evaluate the efficiency of an innovative health technology relative to current care. The basis for such studies are often cost-effectiveness models, such as decision trees and Markov models. The principles of cost-effectiveness modelling were introduced during previous courses. In this advanced course, we will discuss e.g. more advanced model structures, survival analysis, model validation, finding cost and utility input for your model, and how to build a probabilistic sensitivity analysis into your model.
This course is essential for all students who aim to develop a cost-effectiveness model for their thesis.

During this course of 6 weeks, each week will be spent on a specific topic. A lecture will introduce the main elements of that week. In some weeks there will be a working group session where students can ask specific questions regarding that week‚Äôs assignment if they need so. In one week a computer exercise will be done to help students learn how to estimate and extrapolate survival curves from published data.

Subsequently, the excel-based models that were built by the students will be used for feedback sessions, to further develop modelling principles and skills. Two of these feedback sessions will be based on peer review, that is, each group will assess the models of two other groups, and report on them during the feedback session. The third feedback session will be based on model review of the faculty.
The exam is composed of four parts:
‚Ä¢    Final report 40% (20% for introduction to results, group, and 20% conclusion and discussion, individual)
Only the final grade (100%) will be published in Osiris.

column1: This course should help you to get both more theoretical and more practical knowledge on cost-effectiveness modelling. During this course more advanced applications of cost-effectiveness modelling are being studied and applied, based on Markov modelling. For this purpose, students will work on a real life case developing their own model and writing a technical report to present this. Models will be developed in groups of 3 students.
By the end of the course the student is able to:

column2: • set up the framing of an economic evaluation.
• construct, populate and analyse a cost-effectiveness model using a Markov model.
• critically assess models for technical errors.
• deliver a report describing the background, principles, structure, inputs, mode of action and technical features of the model developed.
• discuss the strengths and limitations of the modelling approach taken.

column1: Cost-effectiveness studies aim to evaluate the efficiency of an innovative health technology relative to current care. The basis for such studies are often cost-effectiveness models, based on the principles of health state transition modelling or Markov models. The principles of cost-effectiveness modelling were introduced during previous courses. In this advanced course, we will discuss e.g. more advanced model structures, survival analysis,  finding cost and utility input for your model, and how to build a probabilistic sensitivity analysis into your model.
This course is essential for all students who aim to develop a cost-effectiveness model for their thesis.

During this course of 5 weeks, each week will be spent on a specific topic. A lecture will introduce the main elements of that week. In some weeks there will be a working group session where students can ask specific questions regarding that week‚Äôs assignment if they need so. In one week a computer exercise will be done to help students learn how to estimate and extrapolate survival curves from published data.

Subsequently, the excel-based models that were built by the students will be used for feedback sessions, to further develop modelling principles and skills. One of these feedback sessions will be based on peer review, that is, each group will assess the models of two other groups, and report on them during the feedback session. The other feedback sessions will be based on model review of the faculty.

column2: • It is important for students to have basic knowledge of statistics; students should be familiair with concepts such as the Normal distribution and confidence intervals.

• Only the final grade will be published in Osiris.

column1: The course focuses on the world economy as such and the relationships between countries and trading blocks regarding international goods trade, capital flows and worker migration. The analysis of trade policy measures heavily draws on IO-theories to explain the behavior of a regulator, households and firms. The course starts with a refresher in basic microeconomics topics. The course focuses on current issues in the international economic order, mostly within a general equilibrium framework.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

• The course focuses on the world economy as such and the relationships between countries and trading blocks regarding international goods trade, capital flows and worker migration. The analysis of trade policy measures heavily draws on IO-theories to explain the behavior of a regulator, households and firms. The course starts with a refresher in basic microeconomics topics. The course focuses on current issues in the international economic order, mostly within a general equilibrium framework.
• The students should understand the microeconmic foundations of general equilibrium trade theories, as well as applying them in computer-based simulations of real world situations.

column1: The following inventory control models will be covered in the course:

1. Single-location, single-item systems: standard (r,Q) and (s,S) policies with different demand distributions. Evaluation of service levels and costs. Optimization of policy parameters. Continuous and periodic review models. Deterministic and stochastic lead times.
2. Coordinated ordering: power-of-2 policies, joint replenishment model, production smoothing.
3. Multi-echelon systems: concepts and models, lot sizing, METRIC approach, guaranteed-service approach.</body>

column1: A major part of this course will touch upon the field of Asset Pricing, especially in the lectures regarding the modeling of risk. A proper understanding of risk is fundamental to many financial management applications such as capital budgeting, risk management, portfolio selection and performance evaluation. Subjects include:

column2: • Basics of Portfolio Theory & CAPM: Normative vs. positive, assumptions, testable implications, pricing errors/kernel.
• Anomalies: Size, value, momentum & reversal anomalies, why use sorted portfolios.
• Return and return distributions: Expected return, non-normality, incorporating skewness and kurtosis, the role of expectations and information.
• Utility functions: First principles (nonsatiation, risk aversion, skewness preference), types of risk aversion, downside risk, Stochastic Dominance.
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Students have knowledge of theory on diversification.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into asset pricing models and anomalies.
• Students know how to construct optimal portfolios in mean-variance and non-mean-variance frameworks.
• Students are able to test for the existence of asset pricing anomalies.
• Students are able to conduct performance evaluation on investment portfolios.

column1: With respect to your previous classes in management accounting, this course offers a closer look into management accounting and control topics.

The Institute of Management Accountants (an U.S.-based institution) defines management accounting as ""a value-adding continuous improvement process of planning, designing, measuring and operating nonfinancial and financial information systems that guides management action, motivates behavior, and supports and creates the cultural values necessary to achieve an organization's strategic, tactical and operating objectives."" In accordance with the definition, we will examine various topics concerning management accounting and control discussed in literature and used by managers for decision management and decision control.</body>

column1: Advanced Quantitative Methods is het vervolg op Quantitative Methods (Kwantitatieve Methoden). In Quantitative Methods heb je kennis genomen van de rol van statistiek in wetenschappelijk onderzoek en technieken leren gebruiken om onderzoeksgegevens te beschrijven. Bovendien heb je t-toets, Chi-kwadraat toets, correlatie en bivariate regressie leren kennen. Advanced Quantitative Methods begint met een herhaling van bivariate en multivariate regressieanalyse en bouwt daarmee voort op de eerder verworven kennis. De technieken die behandeld worden zijn betrouwbaarheidsanalyse, factoranalyse, multivariate regressieanalyse en logistische regressieanalyse. Bovendien ligt er grote nadruk op hoe conceptuele modellen naar statistische analyses kunnen worden vertaald (controle, moderatie, mediatie) en de elaboratie van relaties tussen concepten (replicatie, uitleg, interpretatie, specificatie).

De kennis en vaardigheden vergaard in het vak Advanced Quantitative Methods zijn voor een overgroot gedeelte nodig om kwantitatieve analyses uit te voeren en daarmee je onderzoeksvragen te beantwoorden. Zowel in de colleges als ook in de computerpractica wordt bij het vak Advanced Quantitative Methods daarom nadruk gelegd op de rapportage en interpretatie van onderzoeksresultaten.

Het onderwijs wordt gegeven aan de hand van webcolleges, hoorcolleges en SPSS-practica. Thuis en in wekelijkse practica wordt in afgebakende opdrachten geoefend met de behandelde stof. In de webcolleges en hoorcolleges komen de verschillende technieken aan bod maar wordt ook het verband gelegd met de praktische toepassing ervan die in de SPSS-practica plaats vindt.

column1: Banks, insurers and pension funds feature daily in the financial press. The credit crisis has triggered a public debate on the risks, rewards and the costs of the banking, pension and insurance industry. Fundamental questions abound. Why do banks exist? Was it a good idea in 2008 to rescue Bear Stearns, the insurer AIG and let Lehman Brothers fail? What are the cost and benefits of bank supervision? Is there too much leverage in the system? Do financial conglomerates increase or lower the risks for the financial system? What about full reserve banking as an alternative for fractional reserve banking? We extensively discuss the role and risks of the financial industry and the connection with monetary policy.

This course addresses these kinds of questions by digging deeper. Due to asymmetric information it is difficult to match the supply of credit with the demand for credit. The financial services sector is the intermediary platform that helps to bridge the divide, albeit imperfectly. Due to the asymmetric information endemic to financial services, risk management is an integral part of the services. We discuss how financial institutions‚Äô management, regulators and supervisors deal with the various risks they face. Risk management is analyzed on the level of an individual bank or insurer, and on the systems level. Bank runs can be devastating for the entire sector and the real economy. Regulation and supervision are thus an important aspect of the government interference with the financial sector. The interplay between monetary policy and banks is essential for the understanding the risks and behavior of the financial sector at a macro scale.

On the methodological side the course freely uses concepts from calculus such as elementary differentiation and integration rules and concepts from statistics such as distribution functions and densities, means, variances and the covariance. We also use concepts from micro economics, game theory (Nash equilibrium) and macro monetary economics.
The main topics of this course are:

column2: • The industrial organization view versus the asymmetric information paradigm;
• Moral hazard and adverse selection;
• Wholesale banking, relationship banking, asset based lending and adverse selection;
• Risk analysis, Value-at-Risk and heavy tails;
• Bank fragility: Bank runs, systemic risk & diversification, regulation and supervision;
• Systemic risk and the credit crises;
• Monetary policy, interest rate risk and credit risk.
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Students understand the asymmetric information paradigm as the main explantion for the existence of financial services and the problem that this causes.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the risk management of a financial service provider and the systemic risk of the sector.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the interplay between monetary and macroeconomc policy.

• Students are able to: analyze the financial services industry using information economics and risk analysis. The students are able to analyze novel situations not treated in class, but using the class notes.
• Students are able to: analyze the interaction between the financial sector and the monetary economy.
<title></title>

column1: This course is concerned with normative public economics. A choice is made each year from the following topics:

column2: • The first and second welfare theorems
• The theory of second-best and dead-weight loss
• Optimal non-linear income tax
• Optimal participation taxes
• Optimal indirect taxes
• Optimal capital income taxes
• Optimal participation taxes
• Optimal taxes/subsidies on human capital and provision of education
• Optimal provision of public goods and social cost-benefit analysis
• Optimal corrective (environmental) taxes/regulation
• Optimal minimum wage policies

column1: The course links the optimal tax principles to actual policy discussions, for example, the flat-tax debate, the optimal progressivity of the income tax, the top rate of the income tax, taxation of capital incomes, greening the tax system, discussions on the optimal size of the public sector, the role of the government in (higher) education, etc.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• To gain knowlegde of the principles of public finance.
<li>To learn to apply principles of public finance to policy questions like:
<ul>

column3: • How progressive should the income tax be?
• Should the government employ indirect taxes besides the income tax?
• How should the government set the optimal capital tax?
• How does taxation affect human capital investment and how does this affect the progression of the income tax?
• How should the government internalize externalities, for example in the environment?
• How much public goods should the government provide?
• What is the marginal cost of public funds and how should second-best policy rules correct for tax distortions?

column2: <li>To be able to understand:
<ul>

column3: • the concepts of welfare economics and optimal taxation
• the optimal commodity tax and the debate on direct vs. indirect taxation
• the optimal tax on capital income - the optimal taxation of human capital
• the samuelson rule for public goods provision

column2: • To be able to derive and interpret simple optimal rules for optimal policies in second-best.
<li>To be able to apply many concepts from microeconomics and mathematics such as:
<ul>

column3: • differentiation of functions: partial and total differentiation
• the envelope theorem and the implicit function theorem,
• maximization of functions with more than one variable
• using the Lagrangian method of constrained optimization
• models of consumer choice (consumption of various goods, the neoclassical labor supply model, and intertemporal choice.

column2: • To be able to link principles of public finance to actual policy discussions, for example, the flat-tax debate, the optimal progressivity of the income tax, the top-rate of the income tax, the taxation of capital incomes, greening the tax system, discussions on the optimal size of the public sector, the role of the government in (higher) education, etc.
• To be able to conduct simple simulations of optimal public policies on the computer.

column1: The course explores a range of different qualitative methods both theoretically and practically. Over a period of six consecutive weeks, the course considers the implications of doing qualitative research. What does your choice for a qualitative research set up mean for the questions you can ask and the answers you may be given? Which different qualitative research methods are out there, what kind of data do they allow us to collect and what kind of skillset is necessary to use them? The course will elaborate on different streams of qualitative research, such as the interpretive tradition, discourse analysis and critical discourse analysis, participant observation, ethnography, and grounded theory. In preparation of each topic, the students are required to collect relevant data (if applicable students will have the opportunity to use their own data). Through these small assignments students will get a feel for the different methods and how they as a researcher are a research tool themselves. The process of data collection will be discussed in class, and the data will be used subsequently for research analysis methods.
BERMMC003 Qualitative Methods/previous experiences with doing qualitative methods is prerequisite for this course.</body>

column2: <title></title>

column1: <body>The goal of this course is to provide students with in-depth knowledge of a range of different qualitative research methods, and to enable them to develop, fine tune and practice the methodological skills that are needed to think about, execute and publish excellent qualitative research.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87233,2019,Advanced Qualitative Methods,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. AFM Krijnen'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course thoroughly familiarizes students with the theoretical background of qualitative research and its main approaches, including discourse and semiotic analysis, in-depth interviews, focus groups and ethnographic fieldwork, and less traditional methods such as photovoice. It discusses the research process as organic and addresses advantages and disadvantages of the dynamic (and often unpredictable) nature of qualitative research. These discussions are grounded in in-class exercises and close-reading of published research, paying special attention to the flexibility of the analytical frame and the relation between theory and empirical data.</body>

<body>This course provides an overview and understanding of the more commonly used and applied multivariate, statistical techniques and the skills to design, carry out and judge sophisticated, quantitative research projects. Specifically, the course covers statistical techniques needed for data reduction (scale and factor analysis), cross-sectional analyses (multiple linear and logistic regression analysis, path analysis) and for comparative analysis (time-series analysis, multilevel and meta-analysis). The course is 'advanced' in terms of concepts and methods, rather than statistical theory or mathematics. The focus is on real-world applications, discussing the assumptions, limitations and interpretations of a wide range of statistical techniques.</body>

• Use these statistical methods in a sound and creative way, More specifically, they are able to clean and transform data, check for assumptions, conduct analyses, and interpret the output.
• Report on their research design, operationalization, execution of the data analysis, and outcomes of the data analysis and their implications in the light of a relevant research question.

column1: The open-source software environment R (www.R-project.org) is a powerful platform for data analysis and statistical graphics that has become the global standard in statistical computing. R houses an ever-growing extensive collection of tools for statistics and data analysis ‚Äì an attractive basis for thorough exploration of your data. Furthermore, it provides a powerful programming language coupled with flexible graphical capabilities.

This follow-up to the introductory course will focus on programming in R. Basic programming concepts will be covered, such as accessing and altering parts of objects, controlling the order of computations, iteratively performing tasks using loops, and writing functions. We will also take a look at functional programming, and how to use these tools in practice. Upon completion of the course, you will be able to use the power of R‚Äôs programming language for advanced analytic tasks to improve the quality of your research.

column1: IMPORTANT: Students without a background in quantitative and qualitative research methods are strongly advised to follow the internet deficiency modules that are offered by ESHPM. The deficiency modules might serve as a useful refresher to methodology for student who do have such background.
The course builds on students‚Äô existing knowledge of statistics and qualitative research methods.
Workgroup sessions are the core of the course. This is where concepts and methods are put into practice after they have been introduced in lectures and literature.

The focus is not on learning many new (statistical) methods ‚Äì since a solid knowledge of those is assumed beforehand - but mostly on interpreting and criticizing results, combining theory and data, and seeing the big picture. A key element of the course is assessing the design and execution of existing successful and flawed studies.

The course consists of two parts. In the first three weeks, quantitative and epidemiological topics will be the focus. They include causal inference, using causal graphs as a tool for designing quantitative analyses, and advanced interpretation of logistic and ordinary least squared regression results. The next two weeks will be devoted to understanding qualitative research methods, with a specific focus on researching language (discourse analysis) and practices (ethnography), and on formulating theoretically informed research questions. In the final week, quantitative and qualitative methods will be combined and students will present their assessments of several published studies.</body>

column1: This master‚Äôs course is obligatory for HEPL and HCM/ZoMa students. The aim is to enhance students‚Äô quantitative and qualitative research skills, which can later be applied in subsequent courses and in writing the master thesis.
At the end of the course, students should be able

column2: • to compare the role of theory in quantitative and qualitative research
• to critically appraise the quality of published research articles based on criteria that are deemed valid in that research paradigm (quantitative/qualitative)
• to explain the role of causal theories in the design and interpretation of quantitative studies
• to apply directed acyclic graphs and casual theory in the design and interpretation of an analysis
• to translate the results of linear and logistic regression into meaningful causal and associational concepts that apply to specific research questions
• to apply a well-developed understanding of the concepts of statistical significance and effect size in the interpretation of study results
• to recognize different forms of discourse analysis (critical discourse analysis, conversation analysis) and develop a basic form of these analyses
• to evaluate the role of theory in qualitative research designs by using the distinction between gapspotting/problematization and inductive/deductive.
• to judge the quality of observations in ethnography by using the observation dimensions.
• to evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of digital and multi-sited ethnography in ethical and methodological terms.
• to perform a basic ethnographic analysis by analysing empirical data, such as ‚Äòonline‚Äô communication.

column1: This module trains students in methods for both quantitative and qualitative data gathering, specifically in the context of doing research in an international or comparative setting. Students learn various techniques for gathering data and for preparing data for analysis through hands-on assignments.
The module consists of the following parts:

column2: • Gathering/preparing qualitative data: in-depth interviewing, ethnography, and photovoice,
• Gathering/preparing quantitative data: designing original survey questions.
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>Upon completion of the module, the student will be able:

column2: • Describe, compare and assess various methods for quantitative and qualitative data gathering and preparing data for analysis in relation to different research questions,
• Reflect on methodological and ethical issues and assess data quality in criminological research,
• Select the appropriate data gathering methods for research projects,
• Independently gather and prepare qualitative data by conducting in-depth interviews, ethnography, and photovoice,
• Independently gather and prepare quantitative data by designing original survey questions,
• Independently conduct small research projects using different data gathering methods,
• Reflect on the quality of the data in relation to answering research questions.

column1: This course traces the genealogy of individuation as a modality of entanglement. Modern social life and social theory are underpinned by a crucial but contingent ‚Äòpossessive individualism‚Äô. This course traces its origins as a way to doing social theory, i.e., as a way of asking how we might be together without the violence of extraction and domination. We will do so by way of readings of the histories of the commons, and by exploring Agamben‚Äôs concept of a form-of-life in the context of the late scholastic Poverty Dispute. We will try to see how modern capitalism and liberal political theory have their origins, in part, in a socialist conception of poverty and the common life. Liberalism still centers on an individuated conception of what the scholastic philosophers and theologians called dominium. In order to understand the ways modern capitalism and liberal political theory are born out of primitive accumulation, it is vital to understand both their emergence in and out of colonial domination and their gestation in the ongoing plunder of the commons by way of dominium, i.e., by private property. The course explores five alternative, non-individuated, conceptions of entanglement: form-of-life, the commons, the undercommons, incompleteness, and composition.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>Students will be able to think and write about the history of individuation in relation to: a) the histories of the commons; b) the development of modern liberalism in tandem with the capitalist enclosure of the commons; c) the colonial divide  that marks modern liberal thought</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87967,2019,Advanced Socio-legal Studies,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. J Hoevenaars', 'dr. JW Hiah', 'dr.mr. WJ Kortleven', 'mr.dr. NL Holvast']",,"Inhoud
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

Socio-legal studies aim at understanding the complex interactions between society and law. This comprises all empirical investigations into actual human behaviours that contribute to these interactions. It can be very practical or rather theoretical. Socio-legal methods can be quantitative or qualitative and the researchers employ literature- or document-studies, survey methods, internet questionnaires, direct observations, open or structured interviews, experiments etcetera. The research can be situated in the discipline of sociology, anthropology and/or psychology. Socio-legal studies is very different from classical doctrinal studies, and also differs from legal philosophy and legal theory.

This course is meant for master students who wish to deepen their knowledge in a specific aspect of socio-legal research. Following this course requires the successful completion of the master course Socio-legal Studies. This course offers students the possibility to work closely with the socio-legal researchers at the department of STeM in order to gain deep and sound socio-legal knowledge. They can use this course as an elective course or as preparation for their master thesis.

Students can a) deepen their knowledge on a specific socio-legal topic or a classical author and/or b) gain experience in the use of a specific socio-legal research method under supervision of one of the socio-legal researchers. Student and (assistant/associate-) professors decide on the relevant literature, depending on the interests of the student and the availability of our professors at STeM.

column1: How does artistic practice contribute to collective understandings and social solidarity? Is culture disposed toward cooperation or conflict? What fundamental transformations have come about in modern culture? By answering these and other questions, through close reading and class discussion, the course aims to help students:

column2: • ground critical thinking in an understanding of seminal theoretical perspectives
• understand both continuity and change in Western thinking about society
• situate research within sociological thought
• improve analytical and writing skills in dealing with challenging, abstract material

column1: In addition to reading classic texts, we will examine samples of artistic work to reflect on ways in which they might embody forms of social thought.

column1: This course provides an advanced theoretical overview of the sociological approach to art and culture. Major theoretical concepts are examined and illustrated with a wide variety of classic as well as contemporary work. This course will operate as a seminar in which we collectively discuss and debate the ideas expressed in the texts and your own reflections expressed in short assignments. Some classes feature structured debate with assigned roles.

column1: <body>This course covers advanced topics in time series econometrics and forecasting, including:

column2: • state space methods
• regime-switching models
• forecasting with many predictors (factor models)
• forecast combinations
• time-varying volatility and correlation

column1: The focus is on techniques that are found useful in applications to macroeconomic variables (such as output and inflation), and financial time series variables (asset returns and volatility).</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Study state-of-the-art techniques in time series econometrics and forecasting.

• Learn how these can be useful in various macroeconomic and financial applications; with a focus on business cycle analysis and modeling and forecasting asset returns and their volatilities and correlations.
• Learn how to deal with issues, both theoretical and empirical, that an econometrician working in these areas faces.
• Gain experience with actually implementing the studies techniques, learning how to do model specification, parameter estimation and inference, specification testing, and forecasting.

column1: The course targets students with an active interest in behavioural research in management that seek to use insights from organizational behaviour in their own research ‚Äì regardless of whether this is in organizational behaviour, strategic management, innovation management, behavioural operations management, or another area of behavioural research in management. Basic knowledge of behavioural research is therefore required, so the course can concentrate on advanced coverage of the state of the science.

On the basis of review/conceptual articles as well as exemplars of empirical research, the course covers a series of key themes in organizational behaviour (e.g., teams, leadership, creativity & innovation, social networks). The format is a combination of short lectures, interactive discussion, in-class exercises, and guest lectures to develop an in-depth understanding of the current state of play in a series of subareas of organizational behaviour. The bottom line aim of the sessions is to provide input for participants‚Äô own research ‚Äì the course should not only develop one‚Äôs knowledge of research in organizational behaviour, but also lead to actionable knowledge that can be translated into the own research efforts.

column1: <body>The course contains three blocks. Each of them will cover classic and state-of-the-art research in a variety of strategic entrepreneurship topics including their foundational theories and empirical models. Block one focuses on internal corporate venturing, multi-level ambidexterity, strategic renewal, business model innovation, and high-growth scale-up firms. Block two on external corporate venturing, technology sourcing, corporate development, alliances and acquisitions, collaborative innovation, and corporate start-up collaboration. Block three on opportunity-seeking and advantage-seeking behaviors, strategic entrepreneurial leadership, and intra-organizational decision-making and interactions.</body>

column1: We will start by consolidating and deepening the DCF approach through a few selected topics: careful, correct calculation of cash flows, estimating discount rates and alternative approaches (multiples-based valuation, alternative income/cash flow approaches) and the conditions for the equivalence between some of those.
We will also talk about valuation in ‚Äúspecial situations‚Äù such as mergers and acquisitions, startups and other high-growth companies as well as financial institutions.

We will close the course with some thoughts on managing for value ‚Äì why companies should be managed for value and what managing for value means. Throughout the course we will pay some attention to how one can present ideas a variety of charts. Students will apply all these techniques to a company of their choice.

column1: This course provides a solid knowledge of the techniques available for valuing companies. In this respect, the learning objectives are:
¬ª      To understand and be able to apply several valuation methodologies across a range of situations;
¬ª      To understand and be able to challenge their theoretical foundations;
¬ª      To understand how DCF and alternative income approaches (economic profit, residual earnings) are related, their advantages and disadvantages, as well as the use of multiples;
¬ª      What value creation is, how companies create and destroy value, and how value creation can be measured?
¬ª      To argue why companies should or should not be managed for value;</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Consumers encounter communications about brands anytime and anywhere: While commuting ‚Äì via billboards, posters, mobile devices or on the car radio; in the office ‚Äì reading business newspapers, browsing on websites or when opening direct mail; at home ‚Äì watching TV, listening to the radio, interacting with tablets or handling packages; while attending sports events, concerts and movies ‚Äì on tickets, in the program brochure, on the field, on the screen, on clothing. Marketing managers require useful frameworks to effectively communicate and advertise their products and services.

This course discusses all aspects involved in designing effective marketing communications campaigns. The purpose of the course is to get introduced to the major topics in marketing communications and to further develop your communication skills through written projects, team-based work, and oral presentations.

The goal of this course is to help students set marketing communications objectives for a variety of products/services; understand and apply the principles that are necessary for persuasive advertising, from strategic principles (information, influence, emotion and mere exposure) to more specific tactics (resistance, acceptance, message, attention); generate, select and evaluate creative ideas for an advertising campaign; set a campaign budget and select appropriate media (still/motion) for a marketing communications campaign, taking into account strategic and tactical rules for implementation of the media plan; and propose/design an advertising campaign and discuss, present and defend the proposed campaign.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of this course students will be able to:

column2: <li>
recognize, understand and explain the principles behind effective marketing communication
<li>
analyze and evaluate existing marketing communications by identifying their strengths and weaknesses
<li>
create and develop an effective marketing campaign

column1: From Lynx‚Äôs stereotypical ‚Äòlad‚Äô to Dove‚Äôs ‚ÄòCampaign for Real Beauty‚Äô, marketing materials have changed quite radically over the past decades. This course will consider the concept of gender as it is represented and/or constructed in marketing materials, particularly within the beauty market. Essential to this exploration, we will examine the concepts of masculinities and femininities more widely with a special focus on the body. As the body is pivotal in contemporary consumerist societies, an overview of the current conception of the body as malleable will be provided. In order to gain an understanding of advertising trends and themes, we will explore both the producers and content of current marketing materials.

As part of this course, students will have the opportunity to pitch and conduct their own research project related to the overarching focus of the course. This project will be qualitative in nature and will draw on insights from semiotics and thematic analysis.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
